raw_text:
Euronext 'poised to make LSE bid'
 
 Pan-European group Euronext is poised to launch a bid for the London Stock Exchange, UK media reports say.
 
 Last week, the LSE rejected a takeover proposal from German rival Deutsche Boerse - the 530 pence-a-share offer valued the exchange at about £1.35bn. The LSE, which saw its shares rise 25%, said the bid undervalued the business. Euronext - formed after the Brussels, Paris and Amsterdam exchanges merged - is reportedly working with three investment banks on a possible offer. The LSE, Europe's biggest stock market, is a key prize, listing stocks with a total capitalisation of £1.4 trillion.
 
 Euronext already has a presence in London due to its 2001 acquisition of London-based options and futures exchange Liffe. Trades on the LSE are cleared via Clearnet, in which Euronext has a quarter stake.
 
 Euronext, which also operates an exchange in Lisbon, last week appointed UBS and ABN Amro as additional advisors. It is also working with Morgan Stanley. Despite the rejection of the Deutsche Boerse bid last week, Werner Seifert, chief executive of the Frankfurt-based exchange, may well come back with an improved offer. It has long wanted to link up with London, and the two tried and failed to seal a merger in 2000. Responding to the LSE's rebuff, Deutsche Boerse - whose market capitalisation is more than £3bn - said it believed it could show its proposal offered benefits, and that it still hoped to make a cash bid.
 
 Last week the LSE said not only was the bid undervalued, but that it had "been advised that there can be no assurance that any transaction could be successfully implemented". However, it has indicated it is open for further talks. Meanwhile, German magazine Der Spiegel said part of Mr Seifert's negotiations with the LSE were about where to base the future board of any merged exchange. While Mr Seifert has suggested a merged company would be run out of London, the mayor of Frankfurt has raised concerns that such a move could cost German jobs. Many analysts believe German Boerse has more financial firepower than Euronext if it came to a bidding war.
llama3.2:1b: Euronext is reportedly working on a possible offer for the London Stock Exchange after last week's rejection of Deutsche Boerse's bid at 530 pence per share valued at £1.35bn.
llama3.2:3b: Euronext is poised to launch a bid for the London Stock Exchange, following its rejection of a takeover proposal from Deutsche Boerse last week.
The LSE is Europe's largest stock market, listing stocks worth £1.4 trillion.
Euronext already has a presence in London and works with three investment banks on a possible offer.

Euronext, which already has a presence in London, is working with investment banks and may be prepared to make an improved offer.
The LSE saw the Deutsche Boerse offer as undervalued and declined it.
The future of a merger remains uncertain, but both sides are exploring ways to reach an agreement.

qwen2.5:1.5b: Euronext is considering a bid for the London Stock Exchange, with Deutsche Boerse rejected in favor of an improved offer potentially valued at about £1.35bn.
This would increase Euronext's presence in London and expand its market reach worldwide.

The LSE, valued at £1.4 trillion with a significant presence in London due to its acquisition of Liffe and stake in Clearnet, is considered a key prize.
Euronext already has a foothold in London through Liffe.
Despite rejecting Deutsche Boerse's offer last week, Seifert may propose another bid, focusing on potential benefits for the business.
The LSE indicated openness to further talks but stressed that no assurance exists of successful implementation.
Analysts suggest German rival Deutsche Boerse could outbid Euronext if a bidding war occurs.

The LSE has been rejected by Deutsche Börse but has indicated further talks are open.
However, German investor confidence has increased with Euronext's bid, leading analysts to believe German companies might have more financial strength than Euronext due to a bidding war.
smollm:1.7b: Euronext is poised to make a bid for the London Stock Exchange, but its bid was rejected by Deutsche Boerse - the 530 pence-a-share offer valued the exchange at about £1.35bn.
The LSE, which saw its shares rise 25%, said the bid undervalued the business.
Euronext is reportedly working with three investment banks on a possible offer and has already acquired a quarter stake in the London Stock Exchange.
It trades on the London-based exchange in Clearnet, in which it has a quarter stake.
The LSE last week appointed UBS and ABN Amro as additional advisors to Euronext.
It is also working with Morgan Stanley.
Despite the rejection of the Deutsche Boerse bid last week, Werner Seifert, chief executive of the Frankfurt-based exchange, may well come back with an improved offer.
It has long wanted to link up with London, and the two tried and failed to seal a merger in 2000.
Last week the LSE said not only was the bid undervalued, but that it had "been advised that there can be no assurance that any transaction could be successfully implemented".
However, it has indicated it is open for further talks.
Meanwhile, German magazine Der Spiegel raised concerns that part of Mr Seifert's negotiations with the LSE were about where to base the future board of any merged exchange.
While Mr Seifert has suggested a merged company would be run out of London, the mayor of Frankfurt has raised concerns that such a move could cost German jobs.
Many analysts believe German Boerse has more financial firepower than Euronext if it came to a bidding war.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The LSE is poised for a bid from Euronext, which is part of a pan-European group formed after the Brussels, Paris, and Amsterdam exchanges.
Euronext already has a presence in London through their 2001 acquisition of Liffe and operates an exchange in Lisbon.
They are collaborating with UBS, ABN Amro, and Morgan Stanley, and have reportedly working with investment banks to address Deutsche Boerse's rejected offer.
Der Spiegel highlighted concerns about the potential impact on German jobs during a merger with London.
Euronext maintains their financial strength compared to Deutsche Boerse, though their proposal may focus on London-based decision-making.
tinyllama:1.1b: Euronext is reportedly working with three investment banks on a possible offer for the London Stock Exchange, after rejecting a takeover bid from Deutsche Boerse last week.
The LSE's decision not to accept the Deutsche Boerse proposal was made despite the lack of assurance that any transaction could be successfully implemented.
In response, Deutsche Boerse has suggested establishing an independent board for any merged company based in London.
German magazine Der Spiegel has reported that part of Mr Seifert's negotiations with the LSE were centered on where to base the future board.
However, despite not accepting a takeover bid, Euronext remains open for further talks and may want to link up with London if they are successful in securing the Deutsche Boerse merger.
Despite Berlin's concerns about job losses, many analysts believe German Boerse has more financial firepower than Euronext.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The LSE is reportedly considering making a bid for the London Stock Exchange (LSE) as they rejected a takeover offer from Deutsche Boerse, which valued the exchange at around £1.35bn.
This move comes after the LSE rejected a European-wide bid led by German rival Euronext.
The LSE is set to launch negotiations with both parties in an effort to secure the best possible offer and maintain its position as Europe's largest stock market.
Both groups are reportedly working together on a potential merger, which would likely involve the exchange being rebranded from Euronext to maintain its London presence.
phi:2.7b: Euronext is considering making a bid for the London Stock Exchange (LSE).
The LSE rejected a takeover offer from Deutsche Boerse last week and Euronext is reportedly working with three investment banks on an improved proposal.

Despite the rejection, the Frankfurt-based exchange may come back with a better offer.

German magazine Der Spiegel suggests that part of Mr Seifert's negotiations with the LSE were about where to base the future board of any merged exchange, and there are concerns that moving the operations of a merged company from London could cost jobs in Germany.

The LSE believes that Euronext's proposal undervalues the business, and it has been advised that there can be no assurance that any transaction could be successfully implemented.
However, the LSE is open for further talks.
German magazine Der Spiegel reported that part of Mr Seifert's negotiations with the LSE were about where to base the future board of any merged exchange.
While Mr Seifert has suggested a merged company would be run out of London, the mayor of Frankfurt has raised concerns that such a move could cost German jobs.
Many analysts believe German Boerse has more financial firepower than Euronext if it came to a bidding war.

Now they are working with banks to maybe make an offer again.
The London Stock Exchange said their offer wasn't high enough and they want to talk more about it.

Euronext, formed from the Brussels, Paris, and Amsterdam exchanges, is working with investment banks on a potential offer.
It already has a presence in London through its acquisition of Liffe and a stake in Clearnet.

The LSE remains open to discussions but has expressed doubts about successfully implementing a deal.
Meanwhile, concerns have been raised in Germany about job losses if a merged exchange is based in London.
Analysts believe Deutsche Boerse has greater financial resources than Euronext in a potential bidding war.

Euronext, a merged entity from Brussels, Paris, and Amsterdam exchanges, is collaborating with three investment banks for its bid.
The LSE, Europe's largest stock market with a total capitalisation of £1.4 trillion, lists prominent stocks.
Euronext's presence in London stems from the 2001 acquisition of Liffe options and futures exchange.
Clearnet, where Euronext holds a quarter stake for clearing trades, also operates in London.
The company recently enlisted UBS and ABN Amro as additional advisors and is working with Morgan Stanley.
Despite the LSE's rebuff of Deutsche Boerse's bid last week, Werner Seifert, CEO of Deutsche Boerse, might re-evaluate his offer due to the exchange's long-standing desire to merge with London.
The LSE acknowledged that its shares were undervalued in the previous offer and expressed doubt about successful transaction implementation.
Nevertheless, it remains open for further discussions.
German concerns over potential job losses in Frankfurt have emerged from Seifert's negotiations regarding a merged exchange board location.
Analysts generally agree that Deutsche Boerse possesses greater financial strength than Euronext in the event of a bidding war.
